articles.author: Coder
articles.description: The burgeoning digital landscape, while offering unprecedented convenience and innovation, comes with a hidden environmental cost. Data centers alone consume a staggering 2% of the world's electricity, and the Information and Communication Technology (ICT) sector's greenhouse gas emissions are comparable to those of the aviation industry. As software permeates every facet of our lives, the individual developer's role in mitigating this impact becomes increasingly critical. Green coding, a practical approach to sustainable software development, moves beyond theoretical discussions to offer actionable, code-level strategies that can significantly reduce the environmental footprint of IT systems. By adopting energy-efficient practices, developers can contribute to a more sustainable future, r‚Ä¶
articles.title: The Developer's Guide to Green Coding: Reducing Your Software's Carbon Footprint

articles.author: codeqwertyuiop
articles.description: As a third-year student immersed in the world of computer science, my days are consumed by the logic of code and the allure of algorithms. However, while the ocean of theory is vast, it's the crashing waves of practice that truly test the truth. After participating in several campus projects and contributing to some open-source communities, I've increasingly felt that choosing the right development framework is crucial for a project's success, development efficiency, and ultimately, the user experience. Recently, a web backend framework built on the Rust language, with its earth-shattering performance and unique design philosophy, completely overturned my understanding of "efficient" and "modern" web development. Today, as an explorer, combining my "ten-year veteran editor's" pickiness wit‚Ä¶
articles.title: Unveiling the Next-Generation Web Engine My In-Depth Experience with a Rust Framework and the Path to Performance Supremacy

articles.description:
Welcome to my blog! I'm really happy to see you on my another blog also. 
In my college, my final semester also included a paper called 'Open-Source System'. I actually had good marks on that paper as well. But the knowledge about open-source is very basic, no! not basic also, it's like I really don't understand what open source is. The things I get into wrong or misunderstand about open-source are,
"Open source is a free resource." This means "we can use open-source without paying any amount". Actually, this is also a correct meaning, but that sentence is not meant to say this. So, what is the real meaning of this is I will let you know in the 'After' part.


"Open source is Linux only." I really believe that open-source is only about Linux. The only example I gave in my exams was Linux f‚Ä¶
